It all starts with Swedish town planners.
And Swedish town planners- Sergels torg

this is the problem, it was a rectangle
in the middle of Stockholm. And they
wanted to put a roundabout in it, okay? If
they were going to put a circle, you know,
you're wasting this space - no circle. If
you put an ellipse, this is an ellipse,
here it's too narrow, the traffic is
going to get squashed - couldn't do an
ellipse. So they were thinking about what
shapes they could use and they end up
asking this Danish guy, he was actually a
poet and a mathematician like an amazing
Renaissance man called Piet Hein, and
Piet Hein came up with a solution and
the solution was something called a
super ellipse. I'm going to just start
with the equation for a circle; x squared
plus y squared equals 1, ok, if this is 1
this is a circle. Let's play around with
this, but let's enlarge the exponent. So
let's go to x, say, to the 4 plus y to

Let's now start with an ellipse, this is
a really rubbish ellipse. The equation
for this is x over 3 squared plus y
over 2 squared equals 1. And let's do
exactly the same thing. If we were to
turn this to a 4 it gets a bit chunkier.
If we were to then turn it to an
8 you'd get even- it would be almost
looking like the rectangle. So what Piet
Hein who had to try and find a shape for
the traffic to go round in Sergels torg
is that he started so- just say here, this
is the aerial view of Sergels torg, and
he started with the ellipse;

which, as I said before, couldn't do
an ellipse because it's too narrow
here, and he actually increased the
exponent to get what he called
a superellipse. So the superellipse is halfway
in between the actual ellipse and the
rectangle. And the exponent that he felt
was both most aesthetic and the most
practical was 2.5. And it is true that
this was then implemented and Sergels
torg which is- it's got this kind of
horrible kind of obelisk thing
in the centre and at the moment it's right
in the center of Stockholm; but more than
that this shape it became an icon of
1970s design and the Azteca Stadium,
where the final of the World Cup was held,
you look at the roof of the Azteca Stadium
that's a superellipse. And there's loads
of other Danish design that uses this
shape. And what Piet Hein discovered was
that if he was going to make his

superellipse three dimensional 
it looked like
this; and actually it was an ellipse.
Because obviously an ellipse would just
fall over, it's got a peak- the

auperellipse actually stands.
